# Bad Lip Reading

Bad Lip Reading  
---  
[![BLR channel logo
black.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/BLR_channel_logo_black.jpg/220px-
BLR_channel_logo_black.jpg)](/wiki/File:BLR_channel_logo_black.jpg)  
YouTube information  
Channel | 

  * [BadLipReading](https://www.youtube.com/c/BadLipReading)

  
Years active | 2011–present  
Genre | [Comedy](/wiki/Comedy "Comedy")  
Subscribers | 6.6 million

Subscriber and view counts updated as of January 30, 2018.  
  
**Bad Lip Reading** (abbreviated as **BLR**) is a [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube
"YouTube") channel, run by an anonymous individual[1][2] in the music
production business, that spoofs clips from films, TV shows, songs, sports,
and political news stories by [overdubbing](/wiki/Overdubbing "Overdubbing")
humorous vocal work that matches the lip movements of the targets. _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ described the channel as "the
breakout hit" of the [2012 United States
presidential](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2012 "United States
presidential election, 2012") cycle.[1] As of January 2018, the Bad Lip
Reading YouTube channel had amassed over 6.5 million subscribers and over 942
million views across its videos.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bad_Lip_Reading&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The "Bad Lip Reader" behind the channel is an anonymous music and video
producer originally from [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas").[3] The first Bad Lip
Reading video released was a spoof of [Rebecca Black](/wiki/Rebecca_Black
"Rebecca Black")'s song "[Friday](/wiki/Friday_\(Rebecca_Black_song\) "Friday
\(Rebecca Black song\)")", entitled ["Gang
Fight"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1GaKaGwch0U). New music and lyrics
were matched to Black's video to make it appear as though she were singing
about [gang](/wiki/Gang "Gang") warfare. The "Gang Fight" YouTube video,
released in March 2011, earned BLR a million hits and thousands of
subscribers.[1]

More spoof videos followed, including interpretations of [The Black Eyed
Peas](/wiki/The_Black_Eyed_Peas "The Black Eyed Peas")' "[Boom Boom
Pow](/wiki/Boom_Boom_Pow "Boom Boom Pow")" (a [viral video](/wiki/Viral_video
"Viral video")[4] called ["Everybody
Poops"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kQTW7Pd1vqc)); [Taylor
Swift](/wiki/Taylor_Swift "Taylor Swift")'s "[Our
Song](/wiki/Our_Song_\(Taylor_Swift_song\) "Our Song \(Taylor Swift song\)")";
and [Michael Bublé](/wiki/Michael_Bubl%C3%A9 "Michael Bublé")'s "[Haven't Met
You Yet](/wiki/Haven%27t_Met_You_Yet "Haven't Met You Yet")". The latter was
transformed into the "[electronica](/wiki/Electronica "Electronica")-inspired"
["Russian Unicorn"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YjaZNYSt7o0),[1] which
Bublé himself praised as his "new favorite song"[5] and "one of the coolest
things I've ever seen".[6]

In September 2011, BLR branched out from pop singers to politicians with a
"bad lip-reading" of Texas governor and US Presidential hopeful [Rick
Perry](/wiki/Rick_Perry "Rick Perry"). BLR replaced clips of Perry with
invented dialogue matched to his lip movements. After airing on _[The Ellen
DeGeneres Show](/wiki/The_Ellen_DeGeneres_Show "The Ellen DeGeneres Show")_ ,
the video was featured by news and media outlets across the United States,
leading to a sudden surge in Bad Lip Reading's popularity. Following the Perry
spoof, BLR released bad lip-readings of [President Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama
"Barack Obama"),[7] Republican presidential candidates [Michele
Bachmann](/wiki/Michele_Bachmann "Michele Bachmann"),[8] [Mitt
Romney](/wiki/Mitt_Romney "Mitt Romney"), [Herman Cain](/wiki/Herman_Cain
"Herman Cain"), [Ron Paul](/wiki/Ron_Paul "Ron Paul"), [Newt
Gingrich](/wiki/Newt_Gingrich "Newt Gingrich"), and [Rick
Santorum](/wiki/Rick_Santorum "Rick Santorum").

The channel found even more success in November 2012 when it began overdubbing
popular movie and television shows. BLR's version of
_[Twilight](/wiki/Twilight_\(2008_film\) "Twilight \(2008 film\)")_ quickly
went viral, followed by parodies of _[The Hunger
Games](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games_\(film\) "The Hunger Games \(film\)")_ ; _[The
Walking Dead](/wiki/The_Walking_Dead_\(TV_series\) "The Walking Dead \(TV
series\)")_ ; and _[Game of Thrones](/wiki/Game_of_Thrones "Game of
Thrones")_. The videos have been well-received not only by the public, but
also by the cast and creators of the properties being spoofed. In her [online
blog](http://elizabethbanks.com/post/59512067649/a-bad-lip-reading-of-the-
hunger-games), [Elizabeth Banks](/wiki/Elizabeth_Banks "Elizabeth Banks"),
[Jennifer Lawrence](/wiki/Jennifer_Lawrence "Jennifer Lawrence")'s co-star in
_The Hunger Games_ , said, "Bad Lip Reading is awesome. I was introduced to it
by none other than Jennifer Lawrence. Yup — she saw this, people. And she
laughed. And so did I. A lot." Lawrence's co-star [Josh
Hutcherson](/wiki/Josh_Hutcherson "Josh Hutcherson") also praised the video,
tweeting it to his fans. The cast and creators of _The Walking Dead_ have
publicly praised the Bad Lip Reading "Walking Dead" videos on several
occasions.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Expanding his scope yet again, in January 2013 BLR released [a bad lip-
reading](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zce-QT7MGSE) of [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") players,
coaches, and referees, which would go on to become the channel's most popular
video. A [second](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rRqKYXcL-2U) NFL video
followed in 2014,[9][10] and a
[third](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OTRmyXX6ipU) was released in 2015.[11]
The NFL Bad Lip Reading video would go on to become an annual event for the
channel, with each video being released shortly before the Super Bowl each
year.

In December of 2015, Bad Lip Reading simultaneously released three new videos,
one for each of the three films in the original Star Wars trilogy. These
videos found BLR using guest voices for the first time, featuring [Jack
Black](/wiki/Jack_Black "Jack Black") as Darth Vader, [Maya
Rudolph](/wiki/Maya_Rudolph "Maya Rudolph") as Princess Leia, and [Bill
Hader](/wiki/Bill_Hader "Bill Hader") in multiple roles.[12] The _Empire
Strikes Back_ BLR video featured a scene of Yoda singing to Luke about an
unfortunate encounter with a seagull on the beach. BLR would later expand this
scene into a full-length standalone song known as "Seagulls! (Stop It Now)",
which was released in November 2016 (eventually hitting #1 on the Billboard
Comedy Digital Tracks chart[13].) As of late 2017, the "Seagulls!" video is
Bad Lip Reading's second most viewed YouTube upload, and most popular musical
production. In the song, [Yoda](/wiki/Yoda "Yoda") sings to [Luke
Skywalker](/wiki/Luke_Skywalker "Luke Skywalker") about the dangers posed by
vicious seagulls if one dares to go to the beach. [Mark
Hamill](/wiki/Mark_Hamill "Mark Hamill"), who played Luke Skywalker in the
Star Wars films, publicly praised "Seagulls!" (and Bad Lip Reading in general)
while speaking at [Star Wars Celebration](/wiki/Star_Wars_Celebration "Star
Wars Celebration") in 2017: "I love them, and I showed Carrie [Fisher] the
Yoda one… we were dying. I showed it to her in her trailer. She loved it. I
retweeted it… and [BLR] contacted me and said ‘Do you want to do Bad Lip
Reading?’ And I said, ‘I’d love to…’”. Hamill and Bad Lip Reading would go on
to collaborate on Bad Lip Reading's version of _The Force Awakens,_ with
Hamill providing the voice of Han Solo.[14]

The Star Wars Trilogy Bad Lip Reading videos also spawned a second musical
number titled "Bushes of Love", which featured Ben Kenobi singing to Luke
Skywalker about the perils of love. The song would hit #2 on the Billboard
Comedy Digital Tracks chart.[15] [Hamilton](/wiki/Hamilton_\(musical\)
"Hamilton \(musical\)") creator and star [Lin-Manuel Miranda](/wiki/Lin-
Manuel_Miranda "Lin-Manuel Miranda") described the song as "THE summer jam of
2017".[16]

In January 2017, BLR released a Bad Lip Reading of Donald Trump's
inauguration, which quickly went viral, amassing over 36 million views in 2017
alone. YouTube would rank the video at #7 on its list of the Top Ten Trending
Videos of 2017.[17]

In a _Rolling Stone_ interview, the producer behind the Bad Lip Reading videos
said that he first encountered the technique of [lip
reading](/wiki/Lip_reading "Lip reading") when his mother, then in her 40s,
lost her hearing due to unknown causes. While she excelled at lip reading, he
was unable to pick up the skill despite trying: "I was terrible at it."[1]

In 2013, Bad Lip Reading won the [Webby Awards](/wiki/Webby_Awards "Webby
Awards")' People's Voice Award for "Comedy: Long Form or Series". In April
2014, BLR won the [American Comedy Award](/wiki/American_Comedy_Awards
"American Comedy Awards") for Best Viral Video for its "NFL: A Bad Lip
Reading" video. [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart "Patrick Stewart")
accepted the award on BLR's behalf during the televised ceremony on NBC.

On June 8, 2014 the BLR Facebook page announced the release of the full
version of "Modify" by Kniles, a song that has been used in multiple BLR
productions. The fact that this song was used without previous attribution, as
well as stylistic similarities to other BLR-produced songs, have prompted
speculation that Kniles is another pseudonym for the individual behind Bad Lip
Reading.[18]

A Bad Lip Reading of the [Disney Channel original
movie](/wiki/List_of_Disney_Channel_original_movies "List of Disney Channel
original movies") _[High School Musical](/wiki/High_School_Musical "High
School Musical")_ premiered as a half-hour special on July 11, 2016 on [Disney
XD](/wiki/Disney_XD "Disney XD").

## Copyright
dispute[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bad_Lip_Reading&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Copyright dispute")]

One of Bad Lip Reading's works, "Dirty Spaceman", a redubbing of "[Check It
Out](/wiki/Check_It_Out_\(will.i.am_and_Nicki_Minaj_song\) "Check It Out
\(will.i.am and Nicki Minaj song\)")" by [Will.i.am](/wiki/Will.i.am
"Will.i.am") featuring [Nicki Minaj](/wiki/Nicki_Minaj "Nicki Minaj"), was
taken down due to a claim of copyright infringement. It is unclear if
[Universal Music](/wiki/Universal_Music "Universal Music") issued a formal
[DMCA](/wiki/Digital_Millennium_Copyright_Act "Digital Millennium Copyright
Act") [takedown request](/wiki/Notice_and_take_down "Notice and take down") or
if YouTube's Content ID Match system detected the work and removed it
automatically.[19] Also, in March 2012, the video "Beard With Glue," a bad lip
reading of "[You're Beautiful](/wiki/You%27re_Beautiful "You're Beautiful")"
by [James Blunt](/wiki/James_Blunt "James Blunt"), was taken down by [Warner
Music Group](/wiki/Warner_Music_Group "Warner Music Group") on a copyright
claim. Unlike "Dirty Spaceman", the claim was soon released, and the video was
returned. Likewise, "Gang Fight" was taken down in 2011, but returned. UMG has
also taken down "Rockin' All Nite Long", the [Taylor Swift](/wiki/Taylor_Swift
"Taylor Swift") spoof that also features [Wiz Khalifa](/wiki/Wiz_Khalifa "Wiz
Khalifa").
